The results for all baselines BPR, SSM, and SimCE are shown in Table 2. With 12 datasets, 2 model types, and 4 metrics, there are a total of 96 comparison instances. We can observe that models trained with our SimCE consistently outperform both BPR and SSM in 93 instances. In most cases, our method significantly surpasses the baselines, with the maximum improvement reaching up to <math alttext="68.72\%" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1a">

      <mo id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1.1" xref="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1.1.cmml">%</mo>
    </mrow>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1b">

Here, our SimCE only marginally underperforms SSM, making the performance difference negligible. Thus, our method is comparable in these instances as well.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3. Training efficiency. Time stands for training time (sec) per epoch. C. Epoch stands for Converged Epoch where the best performance occurs.
S4.T3.table:
Gowalla iFashion Yelp2018 Kindle Book Movies
Time C. Epoch Time C. Epoch Time C. Epoch Time C. Epoch Time C. Epoch Time C. Epoch
MF BPR 9.0 94 69.5 56 10.9 91 36.7 98 26.6 99 10.5 48
SSM 272.6 9 504.2 8 415.6 9 534.9 11 766.1 8 268.5 12
SimCE 269.6 21 505.6 18 408.3 26 593.2 28 763.2 22 282.5 22
LightGCN BPR 15.9 148 89.9 34 27.2 141 63.4 194 86.1 111 19.0 117
SSM 294.4 15 560.7 6 462.8 18 570.8 19 843.7 17 272.4 22
SimCE 290.0 16 539.2 17 450.5 24 582.5 20 863.2 18 286.5 32
references:
To obtain a deeper insight into the training efficiency of different loss functions, we compute and compare their training time per epoch and the converged epochs where the best performance is achieved. We select six large-scale datasets: Gowalla, iFashion, Yelp2018, Amazon-Kindle, Amazon-Book, and Amazon-Movies. We set the number of negative samples to <math alttext="512" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1a">
    <mn id="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">512</mn>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1b">
      <cn id="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" type="integer" xref="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1.1">512</cn>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1c">512</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS3.p2.1.m1.1d">512</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math> for both SSM and our SimCE. A larger number of negative samples increases computation, making the efficiency comparison fairer. The overall results of different datasets are shown in Table
